channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Toronto School District Cancels Plans for Confucius Institute
item.description: Canada’s largest school district moved to terminate its agreement with the institute, which would have offered after-school Chinese language and culture classes, over concerns about China’s human rights record and restrictions on academic freedom.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: In early 2011, Hu Jintao, left, who was president of China at the time, visited a Confucius Institute at Walter Payton College Preparatory High School in Chicago. The program has entered partnerships with hundreds of schools and universities around the world.

item.title: Secularist Win Is Confirmed in Tunisia
item.description: The results were a blow for the Islamists who swept to power in the 2011 elections after the revolution that overthrew the government of President Zine el-Abdine Ben Ali.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Memo From Ukraine: After Ukraine Vote, a New Test: Burying a Legacy of Dysfunctional Politics
item.description: Dysfunction between presidents and prime ministers has hobbled the country, leaving it one of the poorest on the European Continent and often beholden to the whims of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, second from left, and Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, third from left, at a wreath-laying ceremony last month for victims of a Nazi massacre.

item.title: Troops to Be Checked for Chemical Exposure in Iraq
item.description: A Pentagon review comes in response to an investigation by The New York Times of how troops who were exposed to nerve and mustard agents were treated by the military.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Jeremiah Foxwell, a former naval petty officer who has been granted a partial medical disability for respiratory problems and is under consideration for a Purple Heart.

item.title: Memo From Ukraine: After Vote, a New Test: Burying a Legacy of Dysfunctional Politics
item.description: Dysfunction between presidents and prime ministers has hobbled the country, leaving it one of the poorest on the European Continent and often beholden to the whims of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, second from left, and Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, third from left, at a wreath-laying ceremony last month for victims of a Nazi massacre.

item.title: Activist in Israel Is Wounded in Shooting
item.description: The victim, Yehuda Glick, advocates more Jewish access at a hotly contested holy site revered by Muslims and Jews.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Yehuda Glick in Jerusalem on Wednesday, just before he was wounded during a shooting.

item.title: Egypt Flattens Neighborhoods to Create a Buffer With Gaza
item.description: Demolition began a day after hundreds of homes were evacuated, making room for a buffer zone that officials say will stop militants and weapons.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Egyptian security forces demolished buildings in Rafah on Wednesday near the border with the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Ebola Slowing in Liberia, W.H.O. Says, but International Support Is Still Necessary
item.description: The World Health Organization’s assistant director general said there had been a decline in burials in the West African nation and no increases in confirmed cases.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The reflection on an ambulance window of an Ebola outreach team in Kakata, Liberia.

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: French Commando Dies in Fighting
item.description: France said Wednesday that a French soldier and about 20 Islamist militants had been killed during a fierce clash in northern Mali near the Algerian border.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Army Database Raises Concern About Possible Spying
item.description: The authorities said they were investigating an allegation that the army kept a database of email addresses for people seeking a peace deal with the country’s main guerrilla group.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: Clashes Over Oil Town
item.description: Rebels and government forces both claimed Wednesday that they controlled the oil hub of Bentiu in South Sudan as fighting entered a third day.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: American Fugitive Is Arrested
item.description: The police said Wednesday that they had arrested a man identified by the news media as a United States Army deserter wanted in Florida on child pornography charges.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Austria: Boy, 14, Held in Terrorism Case
item.description: The state prosecutor’s office said a 14-year-old boy had been arrested on suspicion of planning to place a bomb in a busy Viennese train station and could be charged with belonging to a terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Reinforcements Enter Besieged Syrian Town via Turkey, Raising Hopes
item.description: Officials in Kobani, Syria, hailed the arrival of Iraqi Kurdish soldiers and Syrian rebels, saying they hoped it heralded a more cooperative effort to fight the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Kurds in Viransehir, Turkey, greeting Iraqi Kurdish pesh merga convoys as fighters passed through on their way to the besieged Syrian town of Kobani.

item.title: Spike Seen in Russian Military Flights
item.description: NATO on Wednesday reported an “unusual” spike in Russian military flights over the Black, Baltic and North Seas and the Atlantic Ocean during the past two days.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Coast Guard Rescues Cubans Off Boca Raton in New Sign of Perilous Efforts to Flee
item.description: The number of Cubans attempting to immigrate to the United States by sea has nearly doubled in the past two years.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: SAT Cheating Inquiry Delays Scores for South Korea and China
item.description: The Educational Testing Service said it had reliable information that tests had been compromised for thousands of South Korean and Chinese students applying to American colleges and universities.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Israel Jabs Back After U.S. Official Calls Netanyahu a Coward
item.description: A profane (and anonymous) slur prompted an angry (and anonymous) response, in another session of what one analyst called “the nanny-nanny-boo-boo kindergarten school” of geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, with Israel’s transportation minister, Israel Katz, before a cabinet meeting on Sunday.

item.title: E.U. Budget Clearance for France and Italy Comes With an Asterisk
item.description: A commissioner said that while the countries may not have to redraft their 2015 budgets, their filings would face tough scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: The ‘Russification’ of Oil Exploration
item.description: Despite the imposition of sanctions against Russia by the United States and the European Union, Moscow has vowed that drilling will continue.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Rosneft Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A drilling site in the Kara Sea, a Russian sector of the Arctic. After sanctions suspended deals in September, Rosneft began working on plans to drill without the cooperation of major Western oil companies.

item.title: As Abu Dhabi Sizes Up Oil Partners, Western Firms Risk Being Left Out
item.description: The emirate has allowed longstanding concessions to major global oil companies to expire, and is considering replacing some of them with partners from Asia and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By AYESHA DAYA
item.media:description: With oil production surging in the United States and demand in Europe stagnant, Abu Dhabi is sending more of its crude to Asia.

item.title: Obama Could Replace Aides Bruised by a Cascade of Crises
item.description: Stumbles in the handling of the Ebola crisis and the Islamic State have fueled speculation that President Obama may shake up his foreign policy team.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: The president’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, is seen as part of a tight circle.

item.title: Turkish Leader Rushes to Site of Mine Flood
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan appeared determined to act decisively after criticism over his handling of a mining disaster in May that killed more than 300 people.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Relatives of trapped miners waited as rescuers tried to reach them late Tuesday.

item.title: Proposed Internet Tax Draws Hungarians to Streets in Protest
item.description: Under a bill proposed by the government, data traffic would be taxed at the rate of about 62 cents a gigabyte. Critics say it seeks to limit access to independent sources of news.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators held mobile phones as they crossed the Danube on Tuesday in Budapest to protest a proposed tax on Internet use.

item.title: Zambia’s Acerbic Leader, Michael Sata, Dies at 77
item.description: After years working in the opposition and three failed election bids, Mr. Sata became president in 2011, promising to reduce inequality.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Michael Sata, the president of Zambia, reviewed an honor guard in Lusaka in September.
